result.markdown: --- title: "Logical operators" engine: knitr --- ## Logical operators Logical operators are used to compare objects. Every logical operator returns a logical (Boolean) vector of `TRUE`/`FALSE` values. We can then use these `TRUE` and `FALSE` values to create subsets of our data. The primary logical operators that we can use in R are | Operator | Meaning | |:--------:|:-------------------------------| | `==` | equality | | `!=` | non-equality | | `<` | less than | | `>` | greater than | | `<=` | less than or equal to | | `>=` | greater than or equal to | | `!` | returns opposite Boolean value | ## Examples For this example, let's set up a numeric vector `x`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- c(1, 3.5, 7.9, 10, 12.3, NA, 15.8) ``` ::: Now, let's use some logical operators: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x == 3.5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ```{.outputcode} [1] FALSE TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE NA FALSE ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x != 3.5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ```{.outputcode} [1] TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE NA TRUE ``` ::: ::: Notice that the `!` operator changes `TRUE` to `FALSE` and vice-versa. If we want to identify where we have values $> 3.5$, we use: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x > 3.5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ```{.outputcode} [1] FALSE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE NA TRUE ``` ::: ::: If we use the `!` operator: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} !(x > 3.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ```{.outputcode} [1] TRUE TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE NA FALSE ``` ::: ::: ## The OR and AND operators Two other very useful operators are the `|` (the OR operator) and the `&` (the AND operator). These are used to combine two or more logical operations. The `|` (OR) operator returns `TRUE` if any of the conditions are met. The `&` (AND) operator returns `TRUE` if both of the conditions are met. There are other functions such as `any()`, `all()` and `%in%` that you can use to apply OR and AND operators on logical vectors. ### The OR operator Say we want to return `TRUE` if the value of `x` is $> 7.9$ OR $< 3.5$: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x > 7.9 | x < 3.5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ```{.outputcode} [1] TRUE FALSE FALSE TRUE TRUE NA TRUE ``` ::: ::: The table for the OR operator is | `x` | `y` | x \| y | |:-------:|:-------:|:-------------------:| | `TRUE` | `TRUE` | `TRUE` | | `FALSE` | `TRUE` | `TRUE` | | `TRUE` | `FALSE` | `TRUE` | | `FALSE` | `FALSE` | `FALSE` | ### The AND operator Say we want to return `TRUE` if the value of `x` is $> 7.9$ AND $< 3.5$: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x > 7.9 & x < 3.5 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ```{.outputcode} [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE NA FALSE ``` ::: ::: The table for the AND operator is | `x` | `y` | x & y | |:-------:|:-------:|:------------------:| | `TRUE` | `TRUE` | `TRUE` | | `FALSE` | `TRUE` | `FALSE` | | `TRUE` | `FALSE` | `FALSE` | | `FALSE` | `FALSE` | `FALSE` | ## Additional resources
